definition:
*Sudoku* is a logic puzzle, usually consisting of a 9 by 9 grid
subdivided into 3 by 3 squares, some of which are marked with numerals
from 1 to 9 (the givens). The goal of the puzzle is to mark the rest of
the grid so that the result is a Latin square, that is, so that each
row, column, and subgrid has all of the numerals 1 to 9 with no
duplicates.

Given a partially filled $n \times n$ Latin square, the problem of
testing if it extends to a complete Latin square is NP-complete.

Thus, a sudoku usually has 81 squares with about 30 givens. A sudoku can
have a unique solution with as few as 17 givens (or 18 if symmetry of
givens is required), but it’s also possible for it to have as many as 77
givens (just four squares short of solving) and still lack a unique
solution.
